title-group.article-title: The effects of various lubricants on the friction properties of sewing threads

abstract.p: This paper describes an experimental investigation into the effects of different types and amounts of lubricants on the friction properties of sewing threads. In this work, four types of sewing threads, CO, PET-spun, core-spun (PET/PET) and core-spun (PET/CO) were used. Three different lubricant types and lubricant feeding rates (0.5, 1 and 2 g/min) were applied to the sewing threads.

The results of the research show that the type and amount of lubricant have important effects on the friction of the sewing threads. The friction coefficient values of all sewing thread types with paraffin-based lubricant were the lowest among the lubricants. As the amount of paraffin wax in the lubricants increased, the fiber/metal friction forces slightly decreased. To obtain the lowest friction coefficient, a 0.5 g/min lubricant feeding rate and a 2.5–3% lubricant amount should be used for sewing threads.

body.p: The friction properties of sewing threads are important factors for production processes and for determining the properties and performance of the garments created with the threads. Sewing threads rub against each other and other materials at points of contact during apparel manufacturing.1 The friction on the guiding elements of the sewing machine depends on the surface treatment of the thread and affects the tensile force during the stitch formation process. It is important, therefore, to know the friction coefficient when choosing the appropriate sewing thread.2

In the sewing process, the friction force reflects the friction forces between the thread and fabric, between the thread and the guide elements and mechanisms of the sewing machine, and as the friction between the needle-thread and looper thread. The intensity of the friction differs at different places and depends on the main shaft turn and related phases of the stitch formation process.3

During the sewing process, the sewing thread slides over several guide elements between tension regulator plates and through the needle eye, which effects the friction force between the thread and guide surfaces. With the development of modern high-speed sewing line operations, the performance of thread in the garment business has become extremely important.

Research on fibers and threads has shown that the ratio of the frictional force decreases as the load increases.4 This means Coulomb’s law is invalid for fibers and threads. Hence, it also follows that Eytelwein’s law should be used for calculating the friction for threads sliding over a cylindrical guide, which is derived from Coulomb’s law for threads, where F1 is the incoming force, F2 is the leaving force, μ is the friction coefficient and α is the angle of contact in, rad., as shown in Equation (1):2 (1)F2/F1=eμαμ=1/α.ln(F2/F1)

The frictional properties of textile yarns and of machinery components such as yarn guides are of general interest and have many applications. Because the frictional properties of yarns will affect the performance and life of yarn guides, sewing and knitting needles, and other contact surfaces, the modifying effects of surface finishes and lubricants are of special interest. Frictional properties also affect the quality and performance properties of yarns and the products made from them. As a consequence, frictional properties are of interest in research, quality control and product design.6

When the thread slides over the cylinder, the friction, primarily, depends on the sewing thread’s properties, such as its surface finish. Secondly, the friction depends on the guide properties, such as the smoothness and hardness of the surface. Finally, the friction depends on the thread velocity. The friction force can be reduced with appropriate lubrication and by controlling the difference between the static and kinetic friction coefficients.5 Compared with the effect of lubrication on metals, lubrication has a small effect on the friction of fibers and usually does not reduce the value of the friction coefficient below 0.2. This behavior is usually explained as boundary lubrication in which the layer of lubricant does not cover the asperities on the surface. Under these conditions, the role of a good lubricant is to form monolayers on the surface at the contact points and to reduce the contact area between the materials. In this case, most of the friction force results from the force needed to shear the lubricant film itself.7

Sewing thread finishes have a significant influence on the threads’ frictional properties. The lubricant must provide a low and controlled level of friction and be capable of masking the different basic surface properties of threads. The most common methods for applying the lubricants are finishing in a bath and finishing at the rewinding stage. In the second method, the add-on may be 1–2% lower because the depth of penetration is less than in-bath finishing, where the add-on is approximately 4–6%. Sewing threads subjected to higher stresses require an add-on. Wet paraffin treatment is carried out by kiss-roll application on winding machines.4

Lubricants produce a regular level of friction and, for synthetic-fiber threads in particular, provide protection from the needles heat. Without a controlled level of lubrication on the thread during the sewing process, thread breaks during sewing and seam breakdown in wear would occur. Different threads require different amounts of lubricant according to their end-use. Core-spun and spun polyethylene terephthalate (PET)-fiber yarns must often withstand high temperatures when used as needle-threads and thus require a high level of lubricant.8–11

Most lubrication is intended to reduce for fiber-to-metal friction. In a recent publication, it was reported that the amount and character of the lubricant used have a profound effect on friction. For example, disregarding such related factors as heat and wear but considering friction alone between two oil-film-lubricated surfaces, the friction can be 200 times less than between the same surfaces with no lubricant.12

There are numerous types of lubricants that can be used in the industry. These can be divided into three main classes: fluid-film lubricants (liquid or gaseous), boundary lubricants (fluid/solid combination) and solid lubricants. An increase in friction is seen with an increase in lubricant viscosity. The differences between lubricants decrease with increasing temperature. As the temperature is increased, the range of viscosities becomes smaller, and the absolute values of the viscosities are lower.12

Sewing thread lubricants always contain silicone, because the silicone portion provides the heat protection function for sewing threads. This is not an active cooling function, but it does decrease friction. It is accepted that silicones are poor heat conductors but good release agents, which counteracts the melting of fiber components made of synthetic sewing threads.13 The paraffin-based lubricants yield the lowest friction coefficients among the sewing thread lubricants.14

The application of paraffin can reduce the value of μ by approximately 50%. If too much paraffin is applied, however, it begins to soften due to the local heat, caused by friction, then forms an undesirable grease film and actually leads to an increase in friction. The curve in Figure 1 shows the qualitative relationship between paraffin content and the coefficient of friction.15 Figure 1.

sec.p:

Three lubricants with different chemical compositions were supplied by Rudolf-Duraner A.S. (Turkey) and were used in the experiments: their properties are listed in Table 2. One of them (SNV) was a silicon (polysiloxane)-based lubricant for cold melt applications. The others, SCI and SCW, are silicon-containing paraffin-based lubricants. The SCI lubricant is intended for cold melt applications, and SCW, which has a higher paraffin content, is intended for hot melt applications. Table 2.

The tenacity and elongation values of the sewing threads were measured using an Instron Strength Tester according to the TS 245 EN ISO 2062 standard.

Controlled lubrication amounts were applied to the four sewing threads at the rewinding stage on OMR (MDTK/C-3) (Italy) model winding machine. On the electronically controlled winding machine, the lubricant amount applied on the threads can be controlled precisely with the help of the Graf lubricant dosing system.16 The lubrication take-off levels were set on the machine as 0.5, 1 and 2 g/min for each sewing thread.

For constant-speed applications, which are the type most frequently used, the calculation of the Feeding Rate can be described by Equation (2):6 (2)Feeding Rate [g/min ]= (Winding speed [m/min ]×Lube uptake [% ] ) (Yarn count Nm [m/g ]×Lube activity [% ] ) where lube uptake [%] is the lubrication quantity to be applied on the yarn in % and lube activity [%] is the solid matter content of the lubricant used in %.

After the lubricants were applied to the sewing threads on the winding machine under controlled lubricant feeding rates, the amount of lubricant on the sewing threads was measured. A Mesdan Oil Extraction Apparatus (Code 273B) was used to make a quick determination of the lubricant content of the threads.

The fiber/metal frictional forces were measured with a Duranax EFI Friction Force apparatus by adjusting the velocity to 5 and 10 m/min. The experimental conditions that were employed to measure the fiber/metal friction coefficients were a machine-entering strain (F1) of 10 cN, a 180° contact angle between the yarn and metal and a 60-second contact time.
We recorded the maximum friction force (Fmax), minimum friction force (Fmin) and average friction force (FAV) from the device, and Equation (1) was used to calculate the friction coefficient.

SPSS software was used for all statistical procedures. The results were evaluated by analysis of variance (ANOVA) and Student-Newman–Keuls (SNK) test. All test results were assessed at significant levels of α ≤ 0.05. The SNK test results of sewing thread after lubrication are given in Table 3. Table 3.

sec.title: The effect of lubricant type
sec.p: In general, the results show that the effect of various quantities and types of lubricant finish applied to different sewing threads is very significant.

It can be seen in Tables 4–7 and Figures 2–4 that the lubricant type had a significant effect on the sewing thread friction coefficient. Sewing threads with the SNV lubricant have a higher friction coefficient than the other sewing threads with SCI and SCW lubricants, which contain paraffin. The results showed that SCI and SCW lubricants yield much better friction values compared with to pure silicone fluids, due to their paraffin content. Figure 2.

Paraffin wax is an essential constituent of the lubricants used for many types of sewing thread, but silicone compounds are most frequently used because their frictional properties are unaffected by heat. The compositions used vary according to the type of sewing thread and its end-use. In this study, the amount of paraffin wax is 5% in SCI and 15% in SCW lubricants. As seen from Table 2, when increasing the paraffin content for a lubricant the viscosity also increases. Tables 4–7 show that the amount of SCW on the threads is slightly higher than the amount of SCI, which can be attributed to the higher viscosity of SCW. Due to the presence of excess lubricant with SCW, the fiber/metal friction forces slightly increase, and the results in Figure 2–4 demonstrate this effect.

In contrast, the friction values for all thread types are more or less similar to each other. This result can be attributed to the positive lubricant feeding control of the metering pump used in the study.

Figure 5 shows the tenacity values of sewing threads with different lubricants at the 0.5 g/min lubricant feeding rate. Figure 5.

sec.title: The effect of lubricant feeding rates and lubricant amount
sec.p: Different sewing threads require different amounts of lubricant according to their structure and end-use. Synthetic sewing threads require higher levels of lubricant to natural sewing threads. Core-spun and spun PET threads must often withstand high temperatures when used as needle-threads and thus require a high level of lubricant.

CO sewing thread provides good sewing performance but has inferior strength, abrasion and high friction coefficient compared to synthetic sewing threads. The most popular sewing threads available today are mainly the spun PET, core-spun PET and core-spun PET/CO sewing threads.

Tables 4–7 and Figure 6 show that by increasing the lubricant feeding rate over the sewing thread, the amount of lubricant also increases depending on the lubricant and the thread type. The amount of lubricant on the CO sewing thread was higher than that on the other threads at the 0.5 and 1 g/min lubricant feeding rates. The Graf lubrication system suggests Equation (2) to calculate the feeding rate. According to Equation (2), the feeding rate decreases when the thread number increases to maintain the same lubrication uptake. Figure 6.
Lubricant amount for sewing threads with different lubricant feeding rates of the SCI lubricant. CO: cotton; PET: polyethylene terephthalate.
To obtain the lowest friction coefficient, a 0.5 g/min lubricant feeding rate and a 2.5–3% lubricant amount should be used for sewing threads.

The frictional forces and friction coefficient of sewing threads are shown in Tables 4–7. Figures 2–4 show that there was a significant decrease in the fiber/metal friction coefficient after the application of lubricants. For the CO sewing thread, Fmax decreased from 39.8 to 21.3 cN and Fmin decreased from 30.1 to 18.1 cN when the lubrication amount was increased.

Lubricant feeding rates generally have important effects on the friction coefficient. Figure 7 shows that the friction coefficient was increased when the lubricant feeding rates were increased for PET-spun and core-spun sewing threads. Figure 7.
Fiber/metal friction coefficient values of sewing threads with different lubricant feeding rates of the SCI lubricant. CO: cotton; PET: polyethylene terephthalate.

The SNK test results show no significant effects of lubricant feeding rates and lubricant types on the thread tenacity and elongation. However, the sewing thread type has significant effect on the tenacity and elongation.

The results in Tables 4–7 also show that the sewing thread types have significant effects on the sewing thread tenacity and elongation. However, the effects of the lubricant feeding rate on the sewing thread tenacity and elongation were not significant.
Core-spun (PET/PET) sewing thread has higher tenacity and elongation values because of the high elongation level of the PET filament yarn in the core of this yarn.

Contrary to popular belief, the application of a thread lubricant does not increase the tenacity of sewing threads, regardless of the quantity applied. Some thread lubricants, such as silicone oils, can in fact decrease tenacity. This is mainly because silicone oils lubricate the inter-fiber surface area, as a result of their spreading ability, causing the twist to unravel easily and thread break to occur at lower load levels. Emulsion application is a much more optimized application method and offers the lowest strength losses.17

Figure 8 shows the friction forces of PET spun sewing thread at different lubricant feeding rates (0, 0.5, 1 and 2 g/min) of the SCI lubricant. The effects of various quantities and types of lubricants applied onto different sewing threads are very significant. Figure 8.
Friction forces of white polyethylene terephthalate (PET-spun) sewing thread at different lubricant feeding rates of the SCI lubricant.
The SNK test results in Table 3 show the significant effect of lubricant feeding rates on the friction properties.
The coefficient of friction of thread increases rather than decreases after the application of certain quantities of lubricant, affecting the peak tension during sewing.

The application of paraffin can reduce the value of μ by approximately 50%. If too much paraffin is applied, however, it begins to soften due to the local heat, caused by friction, which forms an undesirable grease film and actually leads to an increase in friction. The curve in Figure 1 shows the qualitative relationship between paraffin content and the coefficient of friction.15

It is known that natural fibers have a waxy surface layer that allows them to be readily and smoothly processed. Synthetic or man-made fibers, in contrast, require the application of a finish to make them readily manageable during processing. It is important to realize that lubrication is used as much to control friction as to reduce it.13
The lubricant must provide a low and controlled level of friction and be capable of masking the different basic surface properties of threads dyed with different colors.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The friction on the guide elements of the sewing machine depends on the surface treatment of the thread and affects the tensile force during the stitch formation process. It is important, therefore, to know the friction coefficient when choosing the appropriate sewing thread.

The final aspect of thread construction is that of surface finish, the most important type of finish being lubrication. A lubricating finish applied to a sewing thread should improve the sewability and seam performance. The heat generated between the needle and fabric or the needle and thread is one of the most common sources of seam damage, although it rarely affects synthetic-fiber threads and fabric, provided that the needle is well designed and made from good-quality steel.

Lubricants produce a regular level of friction and, for synthetic-fiber threads in particular, provide protection from the needle. Different threads require different amounts of lubricant according to their end-use. Core-spun and spun PET-fiber yarns must often withstand high temperatures when used as needle-threads and thus require a high level of lubricant. A continuous-filament thread would not generally require as much to perform well.

In this study, we investigated the effects of the lubricant type, friction forces and friction coefficient on four common types of sewing threads with three different lubricant feeding rates. It was found that the friction coefficient and friction forces decrease significantly with the application of a lubricant at a feeding rate at 0.5 g/min for all thread types.

Lubricant type is very important for determining the friction properties of sewing thread. Paraffin wax is an essential constituent of the lubricants used for our sewing threads. The friction coefficient values of all the sewing thread types with Ruco-Fil SCI and SCW paraffin-based lubricant were the lowest among the lubricants used in the study. While the paraffin wax amount increased in the lubricants, the lubricant uptake also increased for the same working conditions and, due to the excess lubricant on the threads, the fiber/metal friction forces slightly increased.

Hot application with the SCW lubricant gives the best results for the friction coefficient. To obtain the lowest friction coefficient, 2.5–3% SCW lubricant at a 0.5 g/min lubricant feeding rate should be used for poly-spun and core-spun polyester sewing threads.
